Definition: In this task, you are given a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to classify the comment into two classes: insult and non-insult. Insult is any lanugage or act that is disrespectful or scornfully abusive.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: your posts shows you are stupid period
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is scornful and disrespectful.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Would you have blamed the Jews for what the Nazis did to them?
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is non-insult because it does not disrespect any group, although the question phrased might be controversial.

Negative Examples.explanation: LOL is an acronym of laugh out loud and is non-insult.
This comment contains explicit language and is considered insult.

Comment: "...“We can say to the alt-right and the neo-Nazis and the KKK: Get over it, you’re African, OK?”..."

Genetically she's correct, but practically she's not.  Read a really good book about two decades ago where the author tried to explain why there are cultural differences between our races.  He basically boiled it down to location.  Races that lived in the more moderate or tropical climates had many means of accessing food and the challenges by the weather for shelter was minimal.  The necessity for technology was minimized.  Cultures in climates farther away from the equator had to not only fight for resource but also develop technologies to advance in the harsher conditions.  Seemed pretty interesting.  It certainly doesn't mean someone from an equatorial climate couldn't successfully enter the more technological environment.  But, there isn't as much necessity for it.

Comment: No, I am really not. Philosophy - from the Greek "philos' meaning love and "sophos" meaning "Wisdom", the love of wisdom - is literally the study of how to think straight.

If you haven't learned philosophy, you will never be able to form a logical thought. No, what people think they are doing isn't logic. Logic is a set of rules. To think logically you have to know those rules, and apply those rules (much like algebra is a set of rules you have to know and apply to get the right answer).

To think you can be logical without studying philosophy is like claiming you can do algebra without learning to count first. 

Here's how it works:
Philosophers figure out how to understand things.
Scientists use those techniques to understand a particular thing.
Engineers use that understanding to solve practical problems.

Unfortunately - because true logic is so often counter-intuitive, those not schooled in it tend to think actual logical arguments are "stupid" because their intuition says so.

Comment: The lower dam was apparently plugged by rafting up logs then submerging them by piling rock on them, to form a latticework plug, of sorts, so why not just dredge them out and let the river flow under the dam, then install a gate to store water for times of drought? The upper dam could have been similarly drilled under to allowed the lakes to refill in flood season, protecting downstream property and then used as a reservoir in Summer. We spent millions of scarce tax dollars for the aesthetics of a "wild" canyon for a few tourists. Once the lakes were drained the dams could collapse in an earthquake with no real harm done, but would likely stand if a seismic sensor automatically opened the drains if things started rocking. Now we have to spend millions more each year repairing flood damage and building new reservoirs, which will likely have their own hazards, and the animals and birds that had come to rely on those lakes for habitat had to move on or die. Idiots R Us. Your tax $ @ jerk.

Comment: That's a good point. The push to CFLs may have actually delayed the adoption of much-better LEDs by a decade. 

The whole complaint about the market not accepting CFL's (and then LEDs) "fast enough" ignores what's likely the biggest reason it's such a slow transition... modern incandescents simply last a lot longer than they did decades ago and consumers typically only replace bulbs when they need replacing.  And they tend to have a supply in the closest to use up first before going out and buying new ones.  

Like CFLs. I probably have 30+ in a cupboard from when Costco was selling them for like $0.99 a 6-pack with automatic Xcel rebate.  So I'm kinda stuck using those for the next 20 years rather than buying LED replacements.

Now, in some high-usage cases I buy LEDs anyway (like the kitchen where the lights are on 6+ hours/day). But I've got so many damn CFLs now that I technically wouldn't have to buy another (regular size) bulb in my lifetime.

Comment: Absolutely agreed.

Both assault and sexual assault see some common issues that work directly against getting convictions.  In both crimes, alcohol is involved in a gross majority of the cases, undermining the quality of testimony, substantially. In both crimes, the vast majority produce no corroborating physical evidence because there's no injuries. 98% of all sexual assaults reported last year had no injuries (type 1), for example. In addition, there's 3rd party witnesses in only a small fraction of the cases for both crimes.  There's generally slightly better chances for witnesses and visible injuries with assault, so the conviction rate is slightly higher, on average, but neither crime sees greater than half of the court cases get a guilty verdict.

Comment: Amazingly, the following post was rejected as "uncivil".  No idea why:

My theory is, let kids run with their own curiosity to what they're interested in, and then sneak in the fundamentals while they're too excited to notice. Example, my grandson and I debated long on why the fight between T. rex and Spinosaurus would have gone exactly the OPPOSITE of how it was shown in "Jurassic Park III" (had they lived in the same part of the world). Got into all kinds of interesting things like how skulls/jaws designed to catch fish would have been crushed by heavier ones designed to dismember big land animals, and why.

Took a while, but he came around. Current struggle is convincing him the giant shark Charcharocles megalodon did NOT live during the dinosaur era (it probably first appeared in the Pliocene, and may have persisted till the early human era). Comment: Auwe! Senate Bill 221, which would have authorized traffic cameras, didn't make it. 

We see them every day, drivers speeding through red lights at intersections, down neighborhood streets, past pedestrians in sidewalks. And we read about them all too often, pedestrians killed or maimed by speeders. Yet the majority of our legislators have given in, once again, to the loud minority who oppose traffic cams for whatever reason. Shame on them. Let's hope that SB-221 comes up again and again until it's finally passed.

Its purpose is not only to punish lawbreakers. It also serves as a deterrent. Just knowing that the cameras are there will force potential lawbreakers to think twice. No one needs to be reminded that a car is a dangerous 2-ton weapon. 

The old law wasn't perfect. The new won't be perfect when (not IF) it is passed. But we can fix that. The next time we read about a traffic death or injury, let's ask ourselves if a camera might have prevented it.

Comment: It's time to start  nurturing the sports fishing industry in Alaska. Commercial fishing has had its day but is problematic going forward. On the other hand more and more people are sports fishing Alaska's fresh and salt water fisheries. Last year almost 300,000 non resident fishing license were issued. Add those to the nearly 150,000 resident licenses. This is an economic engine that keeps growing and that 10 years ago contributed nearly 2 billion economic impact for Alaska. It is likely that it it exceeds 3 billion today. It's hard on commercial fishers, but times have changed and the time when they had the resource pretty much to themselves is over. Much of the money coming from Commercial Fishing leaves the state, yet is erroneously counted in calculating benefit to the state. On the other hand most of the money generated by sports fishing stays in the state and the economic multiplier is very significant.
It is time for ADF&G and the Fish Board to capitalize on this opportunity.

Comment: Actually, there is an office in West Virginia, run by the ATFE that handles firearm tracking and identification for the federal government. Using information provided from gun sales and state registration, guns found at crime scenes can be linked to buyers/owners and used to further/solve criminal cases.

It's called the National Tracing Center, https://www.atf.gov/firearms/national-tracing-center

Tragically the NRA managed to slip provisions into the law in the late 80s that hamstrings the NTC because it won't let them use computers to do the searches, its painstaking labor through literally piles of paperwork. It was covered here: http://www.businessinsider.com/heres-how-cops-actually-trace-a-gun-2016-8

Also Canada closed its LONG-gun registry, due to budget restraints in 2012 and did not change license requirements. See, the RCMP says so: http://www.rcmp-grc.gc.ca/cfp-pcaf/online_en-ligne/reg_enr-eng.htm

Comment: Usually, if you're in a special situation (with infants, or with large luggage or a large instrument), you cannot use the automated check-in machines. I have had this issue flying with a Cello (that I bought a seat for) and with someone that required accommodations (pre booked). Also worth noting, you cannot pre-book seats selection if a leg of your flight is booked through another star alliance member, no matter how much you want to pay. The only way to *try* to get around this is by buying business class tickets and getting the airline to try to accommodate you with phone tag (i do not recommend) because they're just more helpful with business class. This is a pain in the ass with international flights because even though you may book a flight through Air Canada, or Lufthansa, the flight may be actually run by Swiss or any other Star Alliance member. And no, it makes no sense to book each leg with a different airline, you'll end up pay 5-10k for a flight.

Comment: Because human beings, like other primates, are hard-wired to expect a sexual division of labour.  Yes, in hunter-gatherer societies it's the males who went after the big game.  But even in those societies there are many roles that are sex-specific but have nothing to do with size or physical attributes.  The division of sex roles is often quite arbitrary.  With a few obvious exceptions, such as the hunting example you mentioned, it doesn’t really matter what role is assigned to which sex.  The important thing is that they're a binary opposition.  Think de Saussure, think Levi-Strauss.

I’d argue that the perverse attempt to steamroll over human nature is the cause of much mental illness today, particularly gender dysphoria and disorders of sexual attraction.

Comment: UC: Across our country there are newspapers whose editorial policy may be liberal and others whose may be conservative.  It's likely that, as you mention with syndicated columnists, that the RG is more liberal than conservative.  Remember, the paper is privately owned and the staff, including editorial staff, is hired by the publisher/owner.  As I've often mentioned, when visiting relatives in Tulsa, Oklahoma, I read the Tulsa World which is far more conservative than the RG is liberal.....but, hey, they are their papers and their editorial policy is their business.

On the other hand, if papers "slant" news stories and, in effect, mix "opinion" into news articles, that's very different.  If you catch the RG doing that, by all means you should complain....both on this site and directly to the publisher.  IMO, that's not an issue with the RG.  If you think it is, please cite examples.  Regards and a Happy New Year,  Gary Crum

Comment: Aloha e Z,

I only read this now, but I do want to state that I support you in your efforts to make an effective and positive change in, not only the Mililani community, but in the islands at large. I and my kāne may have had differences with some of your opinions (heck we have differences with each othersʻ opinions ;0) but we strongly support your advocacy for the protection of the ʻāina, the keiki, the kūpuna and the houseless. This is what should be focused on - your stance on the issues and, if elected, your follow through, and not what others whom you may be related to or made friends with, etc. do or have done. We should also focus on who you are now and what you will do from today forward. We all make mistakes. Thatʻs part of being human. We can only hope to grow from them. We are not residents of Mililani but own a business here and are invested in this community. 

Ke kākoʻo nei māua ʻo Akahi iā ʻoe. 

Mālama pono,
Pauline Pilialoha Yap, DVM
Ke Ola Pet Hospital, Owner

Comment: MC, First, this site purports to use some mix of "NEA, job survey and private data" to come up with their numbers. In their own words, it's "tricky business". Second, the numbers aren't actual salaries, but are a "comfort index" which tries to give a weighted metric vis a vis cost of living(which can vary a lot within states). Hardly "hard data" to make a policy decision off of, but perhaps useful for rookie teachers looking for work, maybe.  Just having starting and average salaries doesn't tell you the whole story. Averages can be skewed by very  high/low earners, a more useful number is median salary. And again, it doesn't address the total compensation issue, or any other factors that are involved that make one state's situation different from anothers. Still waiting for that comprehensive study to be dug up. I think I'll be waiting a while.

Comment: Pepe LePew,
The State of Alaska assumed the Child Protection Services for Alaska Natives because Alaska was put under PL280, with five other states. Tribes had no say in the matter.

What PL280 is : "Public Law 280 is a federal statute enacted by Congress in 1953. It enabled states to assume criminal, as well as civil, jurisdiction in matters involving Indians as litigants on reservation land. Previous to the enactment of Public Law 280, these matters were dealt with in either tribal and/or federal court."

States : "Enumerated in Public Law 280 were six states which were obligated to assume jurisdiction from the outset of the law: Alaska, California, Minnesota, Nebraska, Oregon, and Wisconsin. States that have assumed at least some jurisdiction since the enactment of Public Law 280 include: Nevada, South Dakota, Washington, Florida, Idaho, Montana, North Dakota, Arizona, Iowa, and Utah." (Note: Metlakatla in Alaska retained rights)

*States can opt out of PL280.
*ICWA 1978 All states

Comment: Officially, the police do not shoot to kill. They shoot to stop the attack. This means continuous firing until the attacker stops moving aggressively. The number of hits that will stop an attacker's aggressive movements varies with the amount of damage each hit inflicts. The amount of inflicted damage necessary to stop aggressive movements is generally massive damage to critical organs. Massive damage to critical organs increases the chances that the attacker will die.
The movie version of "bang...fall down dead" is a myth. As a poster wrote, the attacker in this story went to his uncle's apartment after suffering lethal wounds. That's more like reality.
As to immediate acting tranquilizers or some other disabling drug, where exactly would a person have to be hit for such a drug to act immediately? Under the stress of a deadly attack, would an officer be able to deliver the tranquilizing shot to just the right spot, assuming it is exposed in the first place?

Comment: It's sad to read the many negative comments about teacher's salaries and benefits, especially considering 35 plus students per class. Unfortunately, it's not unusual, in all parts of the country.  I was in high school teaching for four years in California. Left as soon as I could, partly for the lack of support from local school board and community.  Fortunately, the National Science Foundation paid me to get my M.S. degree in Chemistry with all fees covered. I quickly moved on to an outstanding community college at one of the highest paying colleges in the country.  The respect from community, administration, and students was the difference between night and day.  

By having decent salaries and benefits, Eugene is able to attract the better teachers from all parts of the country.  Consider this (baby sitting wages): $10 an hour per student times 35 students equals $350 per class.  Five classes at $1750 a day times 190 days equals $332,500 per year.  $103,000 a year is a bargain!

Comment: It is hard to know where to start with all your poppycock.  The conspiracy theory you hint at is just Looney Tunes.

1) The world *is* most likely headed for a new ice age.  The open question is when.
2) Of course scientists are debating climate change --- that's what they do!  Raising hypotheses and testing them is a core activity of the scientific method.
3) The atmospheric carbon measured for 60 or so years at the Mauna Loa observatory is steadily rising and is composed largely of gases released from the combustion of fossil fuels -- humans are certainly contributing to the unprecedented rise in greenhouse gases.
4) Modern climate models that predict the future might be right or wrong but they all show that the warming trend in recent temperature data will continue and will have effects that our descendants will need to deal with.

You might want to come back after you've done a bit of homework.

-insufficient evidence
-inconclusive evidence
-questionable evidence
-victim unwillingness/inability to provide evidence

Comment: A terrible instance of legalism.  The fact is, though, that unless the men are instituted in the formal ministry of Lector, there is no difference between the women and men who perform this ministry every day throughout the world -- and so your lay pastoral associate drew a false distinction between the women and men who proclaim scripture at Mass.

And thus was born the "Extraordinary" minister.

Comment: Why not cast a white singer in this role? Two reasons: (a) It's still not a level playing field for performers of colour, anywhere. That's just an easily proven statistical fact. If we don't want our stages to be a Whites-Only Zone, it makes sense to give a job to a singer of colour when that role is specifically written for a singer of colour. It will further that singer's career; inspire future singers of colour to say, "Hey, I could do this"; and expose audiences to the talent of artists of colour, which can make people just a bit more imaginative and empathetic. (b) SOUTH PACIFIC is about a white woman who can't bear the thought of mixing the races. Race is a major plot point. If Bloody Mary is black, Asian, or a First Nations mezzo like BC's Marion Newman (who was wonderful in GIIWEDIN a few years ago), we'll still get the basic story... Also, that performer is going to understand that character in a way Sally McWhitebread never could. (I am Sally McWhitebread,  BTW!)

Maybe the intimacy is too scary, maybe he can't perform without having a sense of newness with a partner, maybe he's really a sexless morph who just would rather not get it on very often.

And most often, things will get worse, not better.

Comment: Getting behind the Constitution is as good a place as any to start. The Constitution allots two Senators to each state,  Rhode Island gets two, New York gets two, Hawaii gets two, California gets two, etc.  Size or population is irrelevant. The electoral college is the present system.    A line from the movie "A League of Our Own"  comes to mind.   "Are you crying?  There's no crying in baseball."  The divide is probably not between "elephants and donkeys", but between more fundamental matters such as "Is there natural law or not"?  Is being gay or straight  like being left handed or right handed?  Is life in a mother's womb a human life or is it not?  What constitutes "free speech"? " What are the limits of free speech?  How did we get the notion of political correctness?  Do borders matter?   Will Rodgers once said "We've got the best Congress money can buy".  Has money corrupted the political system? Can the country ever get beyond slavery?  What is an equitable division of wealth?

Comment: That there were criminal gangs in the past is indisputable, but I think BP's point is sound in some respects, it was *for mainstream society*, i.e. MOST people, a less anxious, violent, conflict-ridden society. (Not because of RC faith, but for a variety of reasons.)  New York was well known for its violence, ethnic and other, as was L.A., yet the violence depicted in West Side Story for example was mild compared to what happens today, even in  Canada. It was big news in school if someone got into a fistfight, no one could have imagined using knives and guns and razor blades, etc.

Which is not to say it was better for everyone, in every respect. There are always marginal groups in every society, and being on the criminal margins was no fun, but for mainstream, middle class society, i.e. MOST people, it was safe, I don't see how anyone can dispute that. 

But we still are one of the safest cities in the world, and would like to keep it that way.

Comment: Kudos for not turning this into a partisan political bun-fight, NA.  Harper, Martin and Cretien all had views different from Trudeau. 
But what are our laws if not a reflection of popular opinion? When they no longer reflect popular opinion they are challenged. For example, when three juries refused to convict Henry Morgentaler, it was a reflection of the fact that public opinion on the issue of abortion was changing. The law was thought to be unjust and it was changed. Similarly with laws related to homosexuality. People simply started to ignore them, so they were changed. Same with the issue of marijuana. Because something is written into law does not make it "just", even if the decision comes from the mouth of the Supreme Court itself.
People don't need to be told by lawyers what is right. There are many wacky legal decisions derived from the application of human rights legislation in a legal vacuum.  Rights must exist in balance with society's values, not in isolation from them.

Comment: The media pushes the feel good.  The root cause of America's mass murders lies far deeper than gun purchases.  America is a society that foster's labeling of citizens as valuable or not valuable.  Felons are ostracized for life without a second thought.  People are thrown away in life sentences for offenses less than premeditated murder.  People are placed on sex offender lists for life without recourse.  The prison actions simply reflect the American view that there are good people and bad people and that the latter can be discarded without consequence, care, or compassion.  Trouble is, we teach that respect for life is not universal and thus each individual can frame groups that do not matter and kill them.  The only way to really end the killing is to teach universal respect for our fellows.  Things like prison remain necessary when reform fails, but the routine dumping of life as having no value, is a great teacher, and we pay dearly in terms of consequence.

Comment: Cheating just points out that school discipline is quite separate from criminal prosecution.  I trust you understand a) Title IX requires the school to, in a timely fashion, launch their own investigation and b) the standards for judging the actions are those at the civil court level "preponderance of evidence", rather than the criminal prosecution level of guilty " without a reasonable doubt."  I think O.J. could support that these are very different requirements.  In my post, I specifically reference that many of these alleged rapes and sexual assualts involve "date" or "acquaintance" actions.  There are seldom wittnesses (not a big surprise).  The "rape kits" are usually irrelevant since the defense is almost always "yes, we had sex....but it was consensual."  You need to remember the schools have NO CHOICE but to launch a "genuine" investigation of their own.  It's required by Title IX. Your final sentence "....matter for the justice system, not academic institutions" is not true.

Comment: If two thirds of Canadians do indeed support climate change action (questionable), and if it is a question of how carbon pricing is implemented rather than if (again not fully convinced), then the best proposed plan so far is Michael Chong's national revenue neutral carbon tax.  

Chong's proposal is similar to the BC model, but it is initially revenue negative as large income and corporate tax cuts come first and the carbon price rises in a gradual predictable manner.  In turn a significant amount of government overhead on green funding programs is eliminated, so that markets are left to come up with solutions given the tax signals. 

Trudeau's approach layers carbon tax on top of existing green programs, and of course his additional intervention and spending.  Don't be fooled when he says revenue neutral, as 3 of 4 provinces (so far) have opted for a tax grab.

Comment: Part 2
This conception of church/ekklesia/synagogue was understood by both Jews and Christians to be precisely not a TEMPLE. Both the Jewish temple and pagan temples were understood as the place where God lived. Early Christians had a clear choice for conceiving their buildings as gathering places (synagogues) or as replacements for the Temple in Jerusalem. They chose gathering places.

The PRIMARY focus on the Eucharist as an object of adoration, as the centre piece in a Temple--instead of the "glory" of Yahweh or instead of  a pagan idol --displaced the scriptural notion of the Eucharist as food in the middle ages precisely at the time the faithful we told they were not worthy to receive the sacred food and began not receiving communion almost all of the time they attended mass. Their "consolation prize" was the opportunity to adore the sacred host and chalice as they were elevated at mass; and the opportunity to worship the Eucharist in a tabernacle whenever they visited a church.

Comment: "The president of the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops has called on President Donald Trump to ease the "onerous" contraceptive mandate of the Department of Health and Human Services under the Affordable Care Act because it violates religious freedom."

Under this logic, shouldn't mandating services that cover blood transfusions be deemed "onerous" as a violation of the religious freedom of Jehovah's Witnesses who teach that blood transfusions, even if needed to save a person's life, must not be accepted?  Or should mandating of medical services of any kind be deemed "onerous" as the violation of the religious freedom of Christian Scientists whose faith proscribes healing of physical and mental illnesses and disorders through prayer?

Giving the USCCB position special consideration while ignoring similar "onerous" mandates from the perspective of other faiths could arguably violate the First Amendment insofar as "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion".

Comment: There's an enormous difference between eradicating disease and merely eradicating the people who have it. 

I believe we would welcome the technology to correct Downs and eradicating the condition, with healthy children who would otherwise have it as the result. Just as we welcomed the vaccine to keep people from getting polio in the first place. We didn't just kill off the kids who contracted it and call that a solution. So the analogy doesn't work when you compare the polio vaccine to Iceland's "solution".

Killing people with a disability and proclaiming it to be "eradicated" as Iceland is doing, is an approach that should horrify both these born with handicaps and those who love and care about people born with handicaps.

Comment: The pontifical secret applies to “extrajudicial denunciations”, an allegation of child sexual abuse made to the superior of the accused. It does not apply where a curate is told about the abuse of his parish priest, but vice versa it does. It does not apply where a bishop walks into a priest’s bedroom and finds him abusing a child. His knowledge come from his own eyes and not from any extrajudicial denunciation or any inquiry that he might set up. But these are unusual circumstances. Most of the bishops’ knowledge comes from someone complaining to him about the abuse by a priest under his control, and those allegations are covered by the secret. Those who accidentally come across this information are also bound by the secret. Francis knows about the secret because the Argentinian protocol which was two years in the drafting, was signed off by his fellow bishops one month after he became pope. Art 17 states “as a first warning” that these cases are subject to the pontifical secret.

Comment: This was an excellent assessment of the externalities associated with an industry like coal. All industries have externalities, some more than others. Coal has a lot.
External costs are by definition not included in the up front price of a product or service. This makes the price artificially low, leading to an inefficient market. Changing the free market price point by shifting some of the costs for others to pay means it is not pure capitalism. I think this moves it more toward socialism, like a tax.
Ironically, many socialist countries understand this. In some cases, we understand this too. Taxes are high on cigarettes in part because they cause health problems that cost us all. Same with second-hand smoke.
Burning coal produces the ultimate second-hand smoke. I cannot understand why a free-market capitalist does not call for the price of coal to include these external costs. Could it be they don't care about capitalism, just getting more for themselves at the cost to others?

Comment: Your first argument is not consistent with the statement that you are arguing against. Omitting re-arrests for non-sex crimes has no bearing on the reported re-arrests for sex crimes.

And your second argument is speculation. There is no evidence that a 100% reporting rate of sexual assault incidents would yield any significant differences in the sexual re-offense rate of former offenders. However, whether the re-offense rate is low, high, or unknown, the evidence is clear on what matters here: the current system, which relies heavily on public notification and practices of exclusion, does not create a safer society nor protect potential victims, especially children, from assault. Virtually all child sexual assault is committed by those who are not on the registry but rather a part of the victims' lives and trusted circle of family and acquaintances.

Comment: Wrong again, Tempmanoa.  The thing you call a treaty was not a treaty.  It was the “Agreed Framework” between the USA and the DPRK, signed in October 1994 under which North Korea was to freeze and eliminate its plutonium-producing reactors. In exchange, NK was to receive two light water reactors and annual shipments of heavy fuel oil during construction of the reactors, funded by the Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization (KEDO), a multinational consortium.  The International Atomic Energy Agency sealed and placed surveillance equipment on NK’s nuclear power plants.  NK violated the agreement in December 2002 by cutting off the locks and disrupting surveillance equipment.  It kicked IAEA inspectors out of the country, restarted its nuclear reactors and withdrew from the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty.  Bush tore up nothing.  NK simply refused to live up to the terms of the agreement, causing it to fall apart.

Comment: Wyoming College doesn’t present itself under any false pretenses. It provides a clean-cut Great Books curriculum in a small tightly knit Catholic community in a very healthy environment.

However, they have been granted candidacy status by the Higher Learning Commission which should have them fully accredited by 2018.

Comment: By way of explanation of the comment which elicited your highly articulate 'WTF'...

Subspecies (the biological term for 'race') simply doesn't apply to our species for a variety of reasons.  Firstly, there's no statistically-identifiable character-states which ID any human population as distinct at the subspecific-level.  Even less-so with respect to genetic 'distinctness'.  We're one fairly variable 'race'.  Pretty much a consensus among both anthropologists and geneticists.

Take any set of characters you deem 'racially diagnostic'--length of nasal passages, lung capacity, limb proportions, number of bones in the ankle--for example Scandinavians.  I'll find you another population--example Andean "Indians"--which doesn't look anything like the first, but in whom the above-specified characters fall in the same range.

We all went through a genetic bottleneck tens of thousands of years ago.  Of about 30 past human lineages, we're all that's left, with small remnants of about 3 others.

Comment: It would be very helpful if Ms Ferguson were to lay a charge of rape. This lack of a formal charge leaves all the usual suspects with the opportunity to sit on the fence. This matter is now in the public domain and I cannot think of any downside in the laying of charges.

A little thought experiment. You are judge and jury in this matter and have it in your power to imprison the guilty party based on the allegations made to date in the media. Would you exercise your power of imprisonment based on the information currently available or would you insist that the full judicial process is carried out starting with the laying of charges

Comment: "[T]he Academy of Construction and Engineering has a disproportionately higher population of students who are male (75%) [&] in poverty." How is this the result of "unintentionally created segregation & inequity"? This is a choice district -- if kids who choose ACE tend to be male & poor, that is a reflection of our society as a whole, not a "problem with the SLC system."

As for ACE having a higher student population receiving special education services & disciplinary referrals, earning D/F grades, not attending post-secondary educational institutions, scoring poorly on state exams & being absent from school at a higher rate -- these are obviously the result of ACE leadership. Since the other 3 SLCs in the report did NOT have these issues it's clearly not a "problem with the SLC system."

Yet it was the ACE principal that was chosen to head all 4 SLCs this year. He won't be continuing but it does make one wonder why the district chose the leader of the failing school to lead all four.
